'''Root Force''' is a [[biocentrism (ethics)|biocentric]], [[decentralized]], international [[direct action|direct-action]] campaign devoted to "[dismantling] the system that is killing and enslaving [the] planet and its people."<ref>"Root Force Mission Statement," http://rootforce.org/?q=node/1</ref> The campaign seeks to interfere with the expansion of [[International trade|global trade]] [[infrastructure]] in [[Latin America]] by targeting the corporations involved in specific infrastructure projects.<ref>"What is Root Force?", http://rootforce.org/?q=node/3</ref> Its slogan is "Demolishing [[Colonialism]] At Its Foundations."<ref name="Root Force">[http://www.rootforce.org Root Force<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Root Force was launched in 2006 and is focused on stopping the construction of [[La Parota dam]] in [[Guerrero]], [[Mexico]] and the [[Anillo Periférico]] highway in [[San Salvador, El Salvador]].<ref name="Root Force"/>
==Campaign Philosophy and Strategy==
The Root Force campaign incorporates analysis characteristic of the Latin American solidarity, [[radical environmentalism|radical environmental]] and [[anti-globalization movement]]s.<ref>[http://miami.indymedia.org/news/2006/11/6603.php Root Force Road Show Comes To South Florida! Nov 14 - 15 : Miami IMC<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> According to campaign literature, ills such as environmental destruction, war, and [[genocide]] against [[indigenous peoples]] are caused by a global system and cannot be eliminated without eliminating that system. As examples of the names given to this system, Root Force cites "'[[neoliberalism]],' '[[capitalism]],' 'the [[Sovereign state|state]]' or '[[civilization]].'"<ref>"What Is Root Force?"</ref>
The campaign strategy is founded on the premise that the [[United States|US]] economy depends upon imports from Latin America to continue functioning, and that these imports depend upon "transportation, energy, and communications infrastructure."<ref>"Root Force Mission Statement</ref>. For this reason, Root Force opposes infrastructure expansion projects such as the [[Plan Puebla Panama]] and the [[Initiative for the Integration of South American Infrastructure]]. More specifically, Root Force encourages [[direct action]] against companies involved in specific infrastructure projects, with the goal of forcing those companies to end their involvement.<ref>[http://rootforce.org/?q=node/10 Rootforce.org<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> A list of targeted companies is published on the campaign web site.
Root Force compares this strategy to that used by the anti-[[vivisection]] movement, the anti-[[apartheid]] movement and [[ACT UP]].<ref>"What is Root Force?"</ref> Like other segments of the [[anti-globalization]] movement, it also directs criticism and encourages action against international financial institutions, including the [[Inter-American Development Bank]] and the [[Central American Bank for Economic Integration]].<ref>[http://dc.indymedia.org/newswire/display/136667/index.php DC Indymedia: IADB and other STRATEGIC TARGETS in DC against "growth" and its destruction of Latin America<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>''Earth First!'' 26:6 pp 26-27</ref>
The specific projects opposed by Root Force are the [[La Parota dam]] in [[Guerrero]], [[Mexico]] and the [[Anillo Periférico]] highway in [[San Salvador, El Salvador]].<ref name="Root Force"/>
==History==
An eight-page spread about Root Force was published in the September-October 2006 issue of the [[Earth First!]] Journal.<ref>''Earth First!'' 26:6 pp 21-28</ref> In October 2006, a "Root Force Road Show" traveled the eastern US to publicize the campaign.<ref>[http://rochester.indymedia.org/newswire/display/19715/index.php Rochester IMC: Root Force Road Show Rolls into Rochester<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> As of February 2007, plans were underway for a western road show.<ref>[http://rootforce.org/?q=node/7 Rootforce.org<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In January 2007, Root Force, along with [[Rising Tide North America]], Arizona [[Earth First!]] and a Florida group called Justicia Global, called for boycotts and protests of [[CompUSA]], [[Kmart]] and [[Sears, Roebuck and Company|Sears]] due to links between those companies and plans for [[La Parota dam]].<ref>[http://azef.org/2007/02/08/activists-demand-that-compusa-sears-kmart-end-involvement-in-controversial-mexican-dam/ Arizona Earth First! » Blog Archive » Activists Demand that CompUSA, Sears, Kmart End Involvement in Controversial Mexican Dam<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
